titleStmt.title: Manuscript of "Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa" (Part III).
titleStmt.author: David Livingstone

bibl.title: Manuscript of "Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa" (Part III).
bibl.author: David Livingstone

div.p:
It would have afforded me
pleasure to have cultivated
a more intimate acquaintance
with the inhabitants of
this part of the country
but the giddiness vertigo produced
by ^ by my frequent fevers
made me it as much
as I could do to stick to
the ox and crawl along
in misery - In crossing
Lombe the Lombe my ox Sinbad
in the indulgence of his
propensity to strike out
a new path for himself
plunged into a deep hole
overhead and so wetted
soused me my clothing that I was
obliged to move on
to and dry my thclothing
without waiting on
the ^ Europeans Portuguese ^ who live
on the bank ^ there - But we passed
This I regretted for all the
Portuguese were very
kind and like the Boers
placed in similar
circumstances feel
it ^ a slight to be passed
without a word of
salutation, But we
passed on to a spot
where orange trees
had been planted by the
natives themselves
24 64
and where abundance of that
refreshing fruit was exposed
for sale -

In entering the district of
Ambaca Ambaca we found the
landscape enlivened by the
appearance of lofty mountains
in the distance - The grass
comparatively short and
the whole ^ country landscape at this
time looked graay gray and verdant - On
our rightleft we seeaw the certain
Pungo Andongo rocks ^ of the same nature with those of Pungo Andongo
& which closely resemble those
the group
of Stonehenge The Stonehenge
group on Salisbury Plains only
here have the stone pillars ^ here are of
gigantic size - This district
isregion is all wonderfully fertile
and famed for rearing
cattle and all kinds of agricultural
produce at a cheap
rate - The soil contains
sufficient ferrugineous
matter to impart a red tinge
to nearly the whole of it - It
is from supplied with a
great number of little flowing
streams which unitieng
in the Lucalla - This little
river drains Ambaca then
falls into the Coanza into the
South East at Massangano
We crossed the Lucalla by
means of a large canoe
25 65
kept here by a man who
farms the ferry from the
Government and charges
about a penny per head -
A few miles beyond the
Lucalla we came to
the village of Ambaca an
important place in former
times but now a mere
paltry village on a
beautiful
situation
^ at on a little
elevation
^ in on a plain
surrounded
on haall hands
by lofty
mountains without either
church or fort It has a
jail and a good house
for the commandant
but neither fort nor
church - The signs of
a church though the ruins
of a former place of worship
are still standing

We were most kindly
recievedreceived by the Commandant
of Ambaca Arsenio P. P. de Carpo
who spoke a little English &
He recommended wine for
my debility and here I took
the first glass of that beverage
I had taken in Africa I felt much
refreshed
and could
then realize
& meditate on
the The
eff^ weakening effects of the
fever which ^ They were curious
even to myself for though
I had tried several times
since we left Ngio to
take aLunar observations
I could not avoid confusion
of time and distance - I could
26 66
nor could I hold the instrument steady nor
perform a simple calculation
hence many of the portions
onf this part of the route
were left till my return
from LoandaLuanda often on
getting up
in the
mornings I
found my
clothing as
wet from
perspiration as
if theyit had been
dipped in water - In vain had
I tried to ^ learn or collect words of
the Bunda or dialect spoken
in Angola - I forgot the days
of the week and the names
of my companions and
had I been asked I probably
could not have told my own -
The complaint itself occupied
many of my thoughts - One day
day I I suppose that thought I had got the true
theory of it and would certainly
cure themy next attack whether
in myself or companions
but some new symptoms
would appear and scatter
all mythe fine speculations
which had sprung up
with extraordinary fertility
in one department of my
brain

This district is said to
contain upwards of 40,000
souls - Some ten or twelve
miles to the North of the village
of Ambaca there once
stood the missionary
station of Cahenda and
it is now quite astonishing
27 67
to observe the great numbers
who can read and write in
theis district - Theis is the fruit
of the labours of the Jesuits
ofor they taught the people
of Ambaca usually termed
Ambacistas and ever since
the expulsion of the teachers
by the Marquis of Pombal
Theythe ^ natives have continued to teach
each other - These devoted
men are held in high estimation
throughout this country to this
day - All speak well of them
(os padres Jesuitas) and now
that they are gone from this
lower sphere I could not
help wishing that ^ these our Roman
Catholic fellow Christians
had felt it to be their duty
to give their people the
Bible to be a light to their
feet when the good men
themselves were gone -

When sleeping in the house
of the Commandant an insect
well known in this country
by the name Tampan bit
my foot - It is a kind of
tick and chooses by preference
the parts between the fingers
and toes for inflicting its bite
Its is often seen of from
28 68
the size of a pin's head to that of
a pea and inis common
in all the native huts in
this country - It sucks the
blood untilluntil quite full and
it is then of dark blue
colour and its skin so
tough and yielding that it
is impossible to burst it
by any amount of slqueezing
by the fingers - I had
felt itsthe effects of is bite
in former years and
eschewed all native huts
ever after but as I was
here again assailed in a
native European house
I shall detail the effects
of the bite - These are a
tingling sensation of mingled
pain and itchiness which
commences ascending
the limb untilluntil the poison
imbibed reaches the
abdomen where it soon
causes violent vomiting
and purging - Where these
effects do not follow
as we found afterwards
at Tete fever sets in
and I was assured by
intelligent Portuguese there
that death fby this fever
has ^ sometimes been the result of this fever - From
2930 69
conversation I found on
rising from a dasedaze his
couch - that he had at once
proceeded to cook a fowl
for my use and at
parting he pressed me to
a glass of wine which
prevented a violent fit
of shivering which I expected
that afternoon - The
universal hospitality of the
Portuguese was most
gratifying as it was quite
unexpected - And even
now as I copy my
journal I remember it
all with a glow of
gratitude

We spent Sunday 14th
May at Cabinda Cabinda which
is one of the stations
of the subcommandants
who which are placed at
different points in each
district of Angola for as
assistants of the head-
commandant or Chefe
It is situated in a beautiful
glen and surrounded
by plantations of bananas
and manioc - The
country was daily gradually
becoming more picturesque
31 70
the farther we proceeded West
the ranges of lofty blue
mountains of Libollo which in coming
towards Ambaca we had
seen thirty or forty miles
to our South were now
shut out from our
view by others nearer
at hand and the grey
ranges of Cahenda which
while we inwere in Ambaca stood
clearly defined eight or ten
miles off to the North
were now close upon
our right - As we looked
back towards the open
pastoral
country of Ambaca
Thethe broad green pgently
undulating pastoral plains
seemed in a hollow
surrounded on all sides
by distant rugged mountains and
as we we went West-
wards ^ we were entering upon
quite a wild ^ looking mountainous
district called Golungo
Alto Golungo
Alto We met numbers of
Mambari on their way
Bihe someback to Bihe - Some
of them had belonged to
the parties which had
penetrated as far as
Linyanti and foolishly
shewedshowed their displeasure
at the prospect of the
32 71
Makololo preferring to go to
the coast markets themselves
to entrusting them with their
ivory - They ^ Mambari repeated the
tale of the mode in which
the white men are said to
trade - "The ivory is placed
on the shore in the evening
and next morning the
vender seller finds a quantity
of goods placed there in
its stead - They added to
my men by the white men
who live in the sea" - "Now"
added they to my men
"how can you Makololo
trade with these "Mermen" Can
you enter into the sea &
tell them to come and
ashore - " It was remarkable
to hear this stidea repeated
so near the sea as we
now were - My men
replied that they only
wanted to see for them-
-selves and as they were
now getting some light
on the nature of the trade
carried on by the Mambari
they were highly amused
on percievingperceiving to see the reasons why
the Mambari would rather
have met them on the
Zambesi than so near
the sea coast
3472
keep their families out of the
reach of the malaria which
is supposesupposed to prevail most
Sowels on the banks of the numerous
little streams which run
among the hills -

Canto e Castro We were most kindly
recievedreceived by the Commandant
Lieutenant Antonio do Canto e Castro a
young gentleman whose whole sub-
sequent conduct inspired
m will ever make me
regard him with great
affection - Like all every
other person of intelligence
whom I had met he
lamented deeply the apathy
neglect ^ with which this fine
country hasd been treated -
This district contains a population
which numbered according
inhabitants
which counted
by ^ to the last census ^ was 26,000 hearths
or fires - And if to each
hearth we considerreckon three
or four souls we have a
population of upwards of
1064,000 90,000 - The number
Carregadores of ^ (carriers)^ whose services
may be called for ^ by the commandant several
times a year is 6000
who may be ordered out
at the pleasure of Government
to convey merchandise to
the coast is in this district
alone about six thousand
35 73
yet there is no good road
in existence - This system
of compulsory carriage of
merchandise was adopted
in consequence of the increased
activity of the cruizerscruizers
in suppressing the slave trade
which began in 1845
in numbers and activity
of the ^ our cruizerscruizers which took
place in 1845 Each trader
in the purwho went previous to
that year previous to this into the
Interior in the pursuit of
his calling, proceeded on
the plan of purchasing
ivory & beesbees' wax and a
sufficient number ^ of slaves to carry all he got
these commodities - The whole were intended
for exportation as soon
as the trader reached the
coast. But when the
more stringent measures
of 1845 came into operation
and rendered the easy
exportation of slaves
almost impossible, bthere
being no roads proper
for the employment
of wheel conveyances - this
new system of compulsory
carriage of ivory and
beesbees' wax to the coast
was resorted to by the
Government of LoandaLuanda
36 74
A trader who now requires
two or three hundred carriers
to convey his merchandise to
the coast now applies to the
General Government, for
aid - An order is sent to
the commandants of
a the districts to furnish the
number required - Each
headman of the villages
under him to whom the
order is ^ transmitted the order must
furnish from five to
twenty or thirty men
according to the proportion
that his people bear to
the entire population of
the district - For this accom-
modation the ptrader must
pay a tax to the Government
of 1000 reis or about three
shillings per load carried
Each carrier recievesreceives
The trader is obliged alsto pay
the carrier also, the sum of 50 reis
or about two pence a day
for his sustenance - And
as tha day's journey is never
more than from eight
to ten miles the expense
which must be incurred
by for the compulsory labour
is felt to be considerable
by those who hwere accustomed
to employ slave labour alone

38 75
custard apples and Pitangas
Jambos a fruits brought from
South America by the former
missionaries - The towering
high hills all around with palms
on many points made
this spot appear more
like the Bay of Rio de
Janeiro in miniature
than any scene I ever
saw, and all who
have seen that confess
that it is unequalled in
the world beside - The fertility
evident in every spot
of this district iswas quite
marvellous to behold
but I shall reserve further
notices of this region
till our return from
LoandaLuanda

We left Golungo Alto on
the 24th of May - the winter
in these parts - Every evening
clouds come rolling in
great masses over the
mountains in the West
and rolling thunder accompanies
the fall of rain during
the night or early in
the morning - The clouds
generally remain on the
hills till the morning
is well spent - so that
39 76
we become familiar with
morning mists, a thing we
never once saw at
Kolobeng - The thermometer
stands at 80° by day but
sinks as low as 76° by
night

In going westwards we
crossed several fine little
gushing streams which
never dry - They unite in
the Luinha (pronounced
Lueenya) and Lucalla - As
they flow through liover
many little cascades
they might easily be turned
to good account but
they are all allowed to
run on idly to the ocean -
We passed through forests
of gigantic timber and
at an open space named
Cambondo about eight
miles from Golungo Alto
found numbers of carpenters
converting these lofty
trees into planks in
exactly the same manner
as was followed by
the illustrious Robinson
CruzoeCrusoe - A tree of three
or four feet in diameter
was felle and forty or
fifty feet up to the nearest
branches was felled -
40 77
It was then cut into lengths
of ofa few feet and split into
thick junks - which again
were rejduced to planks
an inch thick by persevering
labour with the axe -
The object of the carpenters
was to make little chests
and they drive a constant
trade in them at Cambondo
When finished with hinges
lock and key all of their
own manufacture they
one costs only one ^ a shilling and
eight pence - My men were
so delighted with them
that they carried several
of them on their heads
all the way to Linyanti -

At Trombeta we were
pleased to observe a great
deal of taste displayed by the sub-
commandant in the
laying out of his grounds
and adornment of his
house with flowers -
This trifling incident
was the more pleasing
as it was the first
attempt at neatness I had
seen since leaving the
establishment of Mozinkua
in Londa - Rows of
41 78
Powell of trees had been planted along
each side of the road
290 with pine applespineapples and
flowers between - This
[ arrangement I had an opportunity of
seeing in several other
districts of this country
for there is no difficulty
in raising any
plant or tree if it
is only kept from being
cloaked by weeds

This gentleman had now
a fine estate which
but a few years ago
was a forest and
cost him only £16 - He
had planted about 900
coffee trees upon it and
as these begin to yield
in three years from
being planted and in
six attain their maximum
theI ehave no doubt but
that ere now his £16
yields him sixty fold
All sorts of fruit trees
and grape vines here yield their fruit twice
in each year without
any labour or irrigation
being bestowed on them
All grains ˄ & vegetables if only sown
do the same and beans
if advantage is taken of
of the fmists of winter even
4279
even three crops ˄ of pulse may be
Cotton was now standing
in the pods in his fields
and he did not seem to
care about it - I understood
him to say that this last
plant flourishes but the
wet of one of the two
rainy seasons with which
this country is favoured
sometimes proves
troublesome to the grower
I am not aware whether
wheat has ever been
tried but I saw both
figs and grapes in bearing
well - The great complaint
of all cultivators is the
want of a good road
to carry their produce
to market - Here all kinds
of food are remarkably
cheap

Fathrther on we left
the mountainous country
and as we descended towards
the West coast saw the
lands assuming a more
sterile uninviting aspect
On our left right ran
the river Senza which
nearer the sea takes the
name of Bengo - It is
about fifty yards broad
43 80
and navigable for canoes
The low plains adjacent to
its banks are protected from
inundation by embankments
and the population is entirely
occupied in raising
food and fruits for export-
ation to LoandaLuanda by
means of canoes - The banks
are infested by myriads of
the most ferocious mosquitoes
I ever met - Not one of
our party could get a
snatch of sleep - I was taken
into the house of a Portuguese
but was soon glad to make
my escape and lie across
the path on the leeside of
the fire where the smoke
blew over my body - My
host wondered at my
want of taste and I at
his want of feeling for
to our astonishment he
and the other inhabitants
had actually become used
to what was at least equal
to a nail through the heel
of one's boot or the
toothache -

As we were now drawing
near to the sea my companions
were looking at everything
in a serious light - One
of them asked me if -
